Dear EECS community, 

Our balloons are still going strong, but their path has considerably separated. 
Looks like NU6XB-12 really likes the Bahamas, — it is now at almost a standstill in a low pressure zone, and is predicted to start leaving the area only in 24 hours. 
However NU6XB-14 was able to catch a ride withe the jet stream and is heading east towards Africa. It is predicted to cross over on the coast of Western Sahara and into Mauritania in about 48 hours. 
Fingers crossed!
Link to the current tracking: https://aprs.fi/#!call=a%2FNU6XB-12%2Ca%2FNU6XB-11%2Ca%2FNU6XB-13%2Ca%2FNU6XB-14&timerange=604800&tail=604800
As I mentioned in earlier messages, we are now tracking our balloons over the ocean using short wave, or HF radio through ionospheric propagation. Here’s a link to reasonably simple notes on the subject: https://www.electronics-notes.com/articles/antennas-propagation/ionospheric/hf-propagation-basics.php
But briefly, the upper ionosphere (also called the F layer) at around 100-500 miles (we call it space, since the ISS and many satellites orbit is at that elevation) has very sparse concentration of small atoms— like Hydrogen and Helium. The sun radiation ionizes these atoms— creating a region which interacts with radio waves —think of it as a change in index of refraction, which similarly affects light passing through a dense medium.  This region has denser concentration of gas atoms at the lower elevation and sparser at the higher — creating a gradient in the index of refraction. This causes the radio-waves to bend, and keep bending till they are completely returned to earth. This skip can be as long as 2000 miles depending on the angle of the radio waves, their frequency and the level of ionization. 
Below I have two photos, courtesy of Prof. Laura Waller. The first figure shows a green laser light in a water tank that exhibits total reflection when transitioning from the denser refraction index of water to air. Most people thing of the upper atmosphere as having the same effect— but this is not the case. 
The second shows the same tank— filled with sugar water. The experiment was designed such that the concentration of sugar at the bottom is higher, and slowly decreases towards the top. This creates a gradient in the index of refraction of light. In th photo, a ray of green laser is refracted and bent due to passing through this gradient till it is  bounced back to the bottom— in a similar way that skyways are refracted  in the F layer of the ionosphere. 
More later!
— Miki
